items.description: Known as "Bozzie" to his mates and colleagues, Mr Boswell's political career spanned three decades.

items.title: Massive early galaxies took different paths, astronomers find

featured_image.name: Mysterious “little red dots” could reveal how the first ...

items.description:
Astronomers have discovered that the universe's most massive galaxies followed strikingly different evolutionary paths in their infancy, with some shutting down star formation early while others remained vigorously active but cloaked in dust.

The findings, presented today at the 247th meeting of the American Astronomical Society in Phoenix, reveal that ultramassive galaxies containing more than 100 billion stars exhibited diverse behaviors less than 2 billion years after the Big Bang[1][2]. The research challenges assumptions that galaxy evolution proceeded uniformly in the early universe.

"What is striking is not just that we can detect hidden activity, but that we see such diversity among galaxies with similar masses at the same epoch," said Gillian Wilson, vice chancellor for research at UC Merced and professor of physics, who mentored the study[1]. "That tells us that the shutdown of star formation in the most massive galaxies was neither uniform nor simple."

items.title: Doctors slam US cut to vaccines recommended for children
items.description: The US government takes the unprecedented step of cutting the number of vaccines it recommends for every child, a move long sought by Health Secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr. But medical groups say it undermines protections against diseases.

items.title: Trump attack on Greenland would mean end of NATO, says Danish leader
items.description: Military intervention in Venezuela has reignited fears about US President Donald Trump's designs on the autonomous Danish territory.

items.title: Nvidia, AMD CEOs unveil AI roadmaps as CES 2026 opens

featured_image.name: Nvidia CEO Huang touts automotive AI at CES talk as competition mounts

items.description:
The annual Consumer Electronics Show opened Monday in Las Vegas with artificial intelligence and robotics dominating the event's first day, as Nvidia and AMD CEOs outlined their visions for AI's future while manufacturers unveiled a new generation of home robots designed to handle everyday household tasks.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang kicked off the show's keynote presentations at 1 p.m. PT, focusing on what he called the "Physical AI" era—artificial intelligence that can understand and operate in the real world[1][2][3][4]. The company unveiled Alpamayo, an open-source autonomous driving platform featuring a 10-billion parameter vision language action model designed to help self-driving cars reason through complex scenarios[2][3][4]. "The ChatGPT moment for physical AI is here, when machines begin to understand, reason and act in the real world," Huang said during his presentation[3][5].

Later Monday evening, AMD CEO Lisa Su took the stage at 6:30 p.m. PT to present her company's roadmap for delivering AI solutions "from cloud to enterprise, edge and devices"[6][7][8]. The keynote, held at the Palazzo Ballroom at the Venetian, highlighted AMD's position in the competitive AI chip market as the company works to challenge Nvidia's dominance[9][8].

items.title: Lula contacts Venezuela's interim leader after US captures Maduro

featured_image.name: President Of Brazil Lula Da Silva Holds A Press Conference

items.description:
Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva spoke with Venezuela's interim President Delcy Rodriguez on Saturday, hours after a US military operation captured and removed Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro from power, according to Brazil's presidency[1][2][3].

Lula called Rodriguez to confirm media reports about the US military action that resulted in Maduro's detention, a Brazilian government source said[2][4][3]. The Brazilian presidency did not provide further details about the call, which marked one of the first high-level diplomatic contacts following the dramatic overnight operation[1][3].

items.title: Live: Khawaja gets hero's welcome for last Test after Head finally falls at SCG
items.description: Usman Khawaja strides to the crease after Travis Head falls for 163 as Australia piles on the runs on day three of the fifth Ashes Test at the SCG. Follow live.

items.title: Hyundai to mass-produce Boston Dynamics Atlas robot

featured_image.name: Boston Dynamics’ Tesla Bot rival Atlas will start building Hyundai cars in 2028

items.description:
Hyundai Motor Group announced Monday at CES 2026 in Las Vegas that it will mass-produce Boston Dynamics' Atlas humanoid robot, with plans to manufacture 30,000 units annually by 2028 and deploy them across its manufacturing facilities[1][2][3][4].

The South Korean automaker revealed the production-ready version of Atlas during its keynote presentation, marking the first public demonstration of the all-electric humanoid robot outside of carefully edited videos[1][5]. The announcement signals a major shift in industrial automation, as one of the world's most advanced humanoid robots transitions from research prototype to commercial product.

items.title: Trump's bombs were as much an attack on China as they were on Venezuela
items.description: Venezuela has spent years getting cosier with China. Now Donald Trump is sending a clear warning to Beijing — get out of his backyard.

items.title: Nvidia unveils AI models, $3,000 desktop supercomputer

featured_image.name: Nvidia CEO Huang to take stage at CES in Las Vegas as competition mounts

items.description:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang took the stage at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas on Monday, unveiling new autonomous vehicle technology and a desktop AI supercomputer as the world's most valuable company confronts rising competition from rivals and its own customers.

In a 90-minute keynote, Huang announced Alpamayo, an open-source family of AI models designed to help autonomous vehicles navigate complex driving scenarios, and Project DIGITS, a $3,000 personal AI supercomputer set to launch in May[1][2]. The announcements come as Nvidia faces intensifying pressure from both chipmaking competitors like Advanced Micro Devices and customers including Alphabet and Meta Platforms that are developing their own AI chips[3][4].

items.title: Live: ASX runs out of steam despite Wall Street rally
items.description: Australian shares retreat into into the red, while steel producer BlueScope gains 20 per cent on a takeover tilt. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

items.title: Live: CIA advised Trump to leave Maduro's deputy in power in Caracas
items.description: As Nicolás Maduro and his wife face court in New York after being captured by US forces, House Democrats leader Hakeem Jeffries has accused US President Donald Trump of lying to the American people about the reason for the attack. Follow live.

items.title: AI capabilities doubling every 8 months, UK safety institute finds

featured_image.name: AI Models Show Notable Skill In Aiding Development Of Potentially ...

items.description:
A leading AI safety researcher has cautioned that rapid advances in artificial intelligence may outpace humanity's ability to implement adequate safeguards, warning that society could be "sleepwalking" into an era where machines control critical infrastructure before proper oversight is established.

David Dalrymple, a program director at the UK's Advanced Research and Invention Agency, told The Guardian that the world "may not have time" to prepare for safety risks posed by cutting-edge AI systems[1][2][3][4]. His warnings come as new data from Britain's AI Security Institute reveals that AI capabilities are advancing at an exponential pace, with performance in certain domains doubling every eight months[5][6][7].

items.title: Sheinbaum rejects Trump military threats after Venezuela raid

featured_image.name: Trump signals more Latin American invasions could be next after capturing Maduro

items.description:
Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum firmly downplayed threats of U.S. military intervention in Mexico on Monday, following President Donald Trump's warnings that Washington might act against drug cartels operating south of the border. The dispute marks the latest escalation between the two leaders after Trump's weekend military operation captured Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro.

"I don't believe in an invasion; I don't think it's something they take seriously," Sheinbaum said during her first press conference since U.S. forces seized Maduro early Saturday morning[1][2]. The Mexican leader emphasized her rejection of any U.S. military presence in her country, stating that Mexico is collaborating with Washington on security but will not accept intervention[1][2][3].

items.title: Maduro pleads not guilty in Manhattan court to narco-terrorism charges

featured_image.name: Nicolas Maduro Transported To Court Hearing

items.description:
Deposed Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores pleaded not guilty Monday to federal narco-terrorism and drug trafficking charges in their first court appearance since being captured by US forces two days earlier in Caracas.

"I am innocent. I am not guilty. I am a decent president of my country," Maduro declared when 92-year-old US District Judge Alvin Hellerstein asked for his plea during the noon hearing at Manhattan federal court[1][2]. The judge then interrupted him, stating, "A not guilty plea will be entered on behalf of Mr. Maduro."[1]

The couple faces charges including narco-terrorism conspiracy, cocaine importation conspiracy, and possession of machine guns and destructive devices[3][1]. If convicted, they could face life imprisonment[3][4]. Maduro has retained Barry Pollack, the Washington, DC-based attorney who secured WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange's release in 2024[3][5]. Flores is represented by Texas lawyer Mark Donnelly[6].

items.title: Dollar hits two-week high after Maduro's capture

featured_image.name: Dollar Gains, Peso Falls as Maduro Exit Fuels Geopolitical Risks

items.description:
Financial markets displayed a measured reaction Monday as Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro arrived at a Manhattan federal courthouse to face drug trafficking charges, following his weekend capture by US special forces. The dollar strengthened to its highest level in two weeks while oil prices remained surprisingly stable, defying expectations of significant market turbulence.

The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index climbed 0.3% to reach its strongest level since December 22, as the greenback outperformed nearly all major currencies[1][2]. The Mexican peso declined 0.7%, and the euro dropped 0.3%[2]. However, the overall market response suggested investors were treating the geopolitical shock as a contained event rather than a systemic crisis.

items.title: Galaxy cluster burns five times hotter than predicted

featured_image.name: Weird clump in the early universe is piping hot and we don't know why

items.description:
Astronomers have discovered a galaxy cluster blazing with gas at least five times hotter than predicted, just 1.4 billion years after the Big Bang, challenging fundamental assumptions about how these colossal cosmic structures form and evolve[1][2][3].

The finding, published in Nature on January 4, describes a cluster named SPT2349-56 whose gas temperatures exceed 10 million Kelvin—hotter and more energetic than many present-day galaxy clusters[1][2][4]. The discovery suggests that the birth of galaxy clusters is far more explosive than cosmologists previously believed, potentially requiring a rethink of galaxy cluster formation models[2][3].
